questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 Finance developer.
You need to create an extension class.
Which action should you perform?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
1. [ExtensionOf(<object to extend>)]
2. mark the class as "final"
3. class name must end with "_Extension"
4. any method existing in the extended class needs to call next() & not have default parameters

choices.B: Add the class buffer as the first parameter.
choices.A: Decorate the class with the ExtensionOf attribute.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an enumeration named truckStatus that has the following statuses:
✑ Empty
✑ Loaded
✑ Completed
You have the following code:
//IMG//

You need to extend this enumeration and add the following statuses to the enumeration: Quarantine, InTransit. You must then modify code that validates the switch statement.
Solution: Add a post handler to the method that checks the enumeration and logic for your new enumeration values using a range comparison for your new values.
//IMG//

Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content: B - No is correct because enums should not be treated as numerical values, as the actual numerical values used to represent each value in an enum are unpredictable, especially in the case of an extensible enum.

Selected Answer: B
You can safely use "<>" numerical operators only on the base enum values (and it is actully used in the standard code pretty often). For the values not from base enum you have no assurance that there is only only extension of this enum, which could mess with the extension value order.

Selected Answer: B
Correct, please refer to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/extensibility/add-enum-value

B - No is correct.
It is not correct to rely on the numeric value of an enum, particularly not if the enum is extensible.

Selected Answer: B
Correct, please refer to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/extensibility/add-enum-value

Selected Answer: B
You can safely use "==" numerical operator only on the base enum values (and it is actully used in the standard code pretty often). For the values not from base enum you have no assurance that there is only one extension of this enum, which could mess with the extension value order.

You need to extend this enumeration and add the following statuses to the enumeration: Quarantine, InTransit. You must then modify code that validates the switch statement.

discussion.content:

Selected Answer: A
Correct, this solution will work always.

Yes, correct.

Depending on whether you have access to modify the code in question, there may be other, easier ways of achieving the result.
However, the described approach will still work, even in such cases.

questions.answer_description:
Instead navigate to the user interface forms section for the SalesTable form and create an extension.
Note: In Dynamics 365 Finance and Operations, the new fields will need to be added via a table extension. Create the extensions on the SalesTable.
Reference:
https://stoneridgesoftware.com/how-to-extend-sales-order-update-functionality-to-custom-fields-in-d365-finance-and-operations/
questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You are adding a new field to the SalesTable form.
You must use an extension to add a status field onto the form.
You need to create the extension in the Application Object Tree (AOT) and add the extension to the demoExtensions model.
Solution: Add a new form object to the project and name the form SalesTable.Extension.
Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
You need to go to the AOT - User interface - forms, right-click the form and "Create extension"
